I think nether mineshafts would be awesome, but here is my issue with it- unlike the non-nether world, there aren't a ton of ores/mineable things when you dig down, especially in nether wastes. It's essentially Netherrack, Magma blocks, sometimes quartz and possibly the nether gold blocks. If this were added, I think there'd have to be a bit more unique ores in the nether that could craft things. This isn't to shoot down your idea though, I just think the discussion needs to move to that first.

I made a post about this that they keep deleting. I'm going to comment it here and maybe it will stay up.

Rainbow after thunderstorm

This should be one of the rarest events in the game.
Every time a thunderstorm ends there will be a really small chance of a rainbow appearing in the simulated area. You must go through the thunderstorm entirely until it ends, if you sleep to skip it this event will lost its chances to trigger.
When a rainbow appears it will be there for a limited amount of time (game ticks). One of its ends will have a chest with valuable loot. The other end will have a chest but it will be empty. The side that has the loot will be chosen at random.
When you close or break one of the chests the rainbow will vanish and the chests will be deleted with all of their contents (if any). This means that you can only visit one of the sides and you get only one chance to find the loot.

In multiplayer, if there are at least 1 player inside the same chunk as both of the chests the rainbow will vanish instantly. This means that if all the players of a world are going to the rainbow they must visit the same side, otherwise it will dissapear.

The rainbow can be made out of particles in a way similar to the fireworks or maybe it can be implemented in a way similar to the clouds generation.

I think this can be a really awesome and fun addition to Minecraft that will make us, the players, more aware of the weather and will keep us excited and expectating while working in other projects or by just playing the game no matter the way you enjoy it.
It’s a good idea!

I think bigger ships would be incredibly fun to explore. Bigger wooden ships with more chest and more levels to the ship maybe 3 or 4 with areas like a bed area, kitchen, supply area or closet, captains courters, spare rowboat area, panty. There can also be vines and paintings on the wall or swords and stuff in item frames. The chest can have better loot and have the bigger ships be more rare than smaller ones. There chest loot tables can be decided into categories like food that has a bunch of food types, moss stuff, saplings, and bad foods like fermented spider eyes. Mob loot chest. Sea chest including coral stuff and uncooked fish or fish in a bucket or empty buckets. a potion chest with water breathing and regeneration and other potions and potion ingredients. Tool barrel of varying tools including an enchanted trident. one for enchanted books. all loot will be in barrels and the valuables in a chest in the captains courter would be cool with valuables being the normal loot from the smaller ships with diamonds and iron but have maybe 2 treasure chest maps in it and other maps like village and woodland mansion maps. The ship could have drowns around or in it. Have some of the barrels on the sea floor near the ship as if they fell off the ship. Make a variant of the ship in coral reefs with coral plants going through the ship with tropical fish swimming through it. another variant could be it having sunk onto spikes in the sea floor.

These are all nice ore ideas, but for the most part, they are just going to be a nuisance if they are only useful for decoration or collecting. Tell us how you would integrate all of these minerals and metals into the rest of the game!

Remember, that for each item added, all of it's forms, textures and world interactions need to be taken into account, as well as how it's availability impacts all the other items in the world.
That's not to say that one should or shouldn't add additional ores and gems, but that given the work and potential for problems when something new is added and begins interacting with the rest of the established game, firm justification should be given for each new item/block type.
Yes yes yes yes!

raw Metals

Zinc, tin, nickel, chromium, and copper.

Copper alloys

Iron alloys

Iron could be alloyed with coal to get steel which can mine diamonds steel can be alloyed with chromium and nickel to create stainless steel which is faster than iron and steel when mining and in combat and cannot corrode iron copper and iron corrode and steel corrodes slower but it still corrodes.

Some things I would like to add are: 

  • Bridges to connect separated mountains.
  • Naturally spawning snow golems (Because it snows on tall mountains).
  • The villages would use redstone torches instead of regular ones not to melt the snow (or any light source that doesn't melt snow such as blue torches). 
  • Llama farms. 
  • Lastly, a feature where you can take snow in a bucket, and when you put it on a furnace or campfire, it turns into a water bucket. This would explain how the villagers get water and gives a reason for them not to melt the snow.
It definitely makes since because emeralds spawn a lot more in extreme hills
Emeralds ONLY spawn in extreme hill biomes and villages so a mine is another good idea for this concept.

Blue torches do not fit their biome and redstone torches emit too weak light. This would lead to monsters spawning inside their houses and kill the villagers.

Instead, I created a fine lamppost. It is cobblestone block, on the cobble block is a cobblestone wall and there is a regular torch on the wall. It gives off a great light and doesn't melt the snow, if you want the snow not to melt.

I would like to see a more advanced village of some sort on the side of the hills in the extreme hills biome. Kinda like you may have to work your way up to the village and when your there you can explore a little town that is a little noted advanced then a normal village you would find.
